post_text: Congratulations to Carolyne Chang on her AP Art Sustained Investigation. "My concentration revolves around the investigation of objects that are transparent, reflective, iridescent, or alters the effects of light. Glass, crystal, and iridescent film are examples of materials that give a new dimension to light. My work began as an exact depiction of transparent and reflective objects in real life; I created still lifes with such objects and simply painted or drew them. As I progressed with my investigation, I began to digitally alter the colors in the original still-lifes, creating a whole new feel to the image."

post_text: Congratulations to Kate Weber for her AP Art Sustained Investigation. "The pieces in my sustained investigation are meant to connect the viewer to my Peruvian culture. The drawings highlight the importance of the textiles that the people hand dye and wear, the dances that are celebrated across the country, the friendliness of the people, and their connection to nature and livestock. The pieces are enhanced with rich, saturated color and a focus on the people from the country in hopes that the series inspires others to learn more about the country and its inhabitants."

Last week's the Girls Who Code club was visited by two women from the Girls Who Code national office and Donna Kalajian Lagani. Ms Lagani was the publisher of Cosmopolitan and other notable magazines for many years before moving to the Hearst Foundation to pursue philanthropic interests.

Ms Lagani spoke to the club about the importance of learning computer science and having female representation in the male dominated industry. She also took great interest the recent activities of our Girls Who Code club which included studying Grace Hopper, a computer science pioneer who was a US Navy Admiral and one of the first people to ever program a computer, and learning about how to build apps using a coding platform called Thunkable.
